OK, yes mass is equivalent to energy and vice versa, but this does not mean that mass is energy in a literal, physical sense. Mathematically they are the same thing and physical equations make no distinction between them, but in the real world there is a difference.
 
 Current physical theory explains the phenomena of mass and inertia by attributing them to something called the Higgs field. 
 
 All particles can be thought of as also existing as waves or fields according to quantum mechanics; the particle constituents of gravity, electromagnetism, strong and weak nuclear forces - gravitons (unproven), photons, gluons, W & Z particles - make up 'force fields', and physics has no problem thinking of the particle constituents of matter - quarks and electrons - making a 'matter field'.
 
 The Higgs field - named after the Scottish physicist Peter Higgs is believed by many physicists to be a third kind of field that permeates the entire universe. The way in which different particles interact with the Higgs field gives them their various properties, and the Higgs field resists their acceleration through space to greater or lesser degrees. A photon encounters no resistance from the Higgs field and so travels as fast as it can.
 
 There is no current theoretical framework for why the different particles are resisted more or less strongly by the Higgs field, but physicists believe that if there were no Higgs field all particles would behave like photons and have no mass whatsoever. 
 
 This is what physicists believe the universe was like prior to 10^-11 seconds after the Big Bang when the universe's temperature dropped to a million billion degrees Kelvin, the temperature at which the Higgs field stopps oscillating wildly and 'condenses' to a stable value. (While it was oscillating it would have had an average value of zero hence having no effect on particles).
 
 The theory has yet to be tested because of the enormously energetic conditions under which it is believed Higgs particles can be 'knocked' out of the Higgs field, but the Large Hadron Collider in Switzerland which is set to begin operating in 2007 should be able to create the conditions which will provide experimental data.

 Yeah sorry I didn't explain it very well; basically special relativity says:
 "the combined speed of any object's motion through space and its motion through time is always precisely equal to the speed of light." - the central concept underlying the notion of spacetime as opposed to space and time.

Light is the fastest thing in the universe because that is how we have decided to conceptualize our world. In very real terms everything in the universe is travelling at the speed of light, most things have split this motion between time and space.
 
 Light is an extreme... it has all of it's motion in space... therefore it travels through space as fast as it is possible to travel.
 
 We on the other had have almost all of our motion in time. Very little in space. We are still traveling at the speed of light, it is just that our motion is almost entirely through time. There are few things in the universe that get "older" faster than us.
 
 Likewise, there is nothing in the universe that can cover space faster than a light beam. 
 
 The reason light is affected by gravity is not because it has mass... but because things with mass warp the space around them, and light beams follow the curves and contours of this warped space.
 
 The whole mass - gravity thing is an approximation we call "Newtonian Mechanics" A very powerful concept for describing gravity on everyday terms, but not very exact when describing objects that travel at extremes. You would use General Relativity in the latter case.
 
 When you look at a light beam and marvel at the space it seems to quickly move through, think about that light beam and how it marvels at how fast we travel through time.... we are an impossible fleeting streak to them, blasting through time almost as fast as the universe will allow.

Physicists now say that neutrinos have mass. Formerly thought to be 'ghostly particles' with no mass, neutrinos can travel, apparently, right through the Earth without interacting with any matter. 
 
 A BBC report describes how to examine their properties, scientists created muon neutrinos in a particle accelerator at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab) in Illinois, US.
 
 A high intensity beam of these particles was fired through a particle detector at Fermilab, and then to another particle detector 450 miles away in a disused mine in Soudan, US. 
 
 A number of neutrinos "disappeared" en route - converting, it is thought, into another type of neutrino. Physicists call the process of transforming from one type of neutrino into another flavour oscillation.  I see your problem. There is no "objective" time. The major breakthrough that Einstien made was to realize that time is relative. The rate at which time moves depends on the motion of the observer relative to that which is being observed. Using your example, from the point of view of someone outside the ship, the trip took 20 years, the distance was 10 light years, so the speed was half the speed of light. From the point of view of the guy in the ship, the trip will take 17.3 years, and the distance would be 8.66 light years, so his speed is still half the speed of light, from his point of view. Both time and space are relative, and they change in the same ratio.
 
 You also asked about how to measure time when traveling near the speed of light. You would do it in the regular way, your watch would work just fine. After all, you're traveling at almost the speed of light right now, relative to something in the universe. As long as your watch isn't moving relative to you, it will always operate as you would expect, no matter how fast you're moving relative to something else. Time always seems to more normally for you; it's other people that will seem to be moving too fast or too slow.
